description: From Latin sinuatus, past participle of sinuare (“to wind, bend”), from sinus (“a bend”). See also sine, from Latin sinus.

adjectives.description: sinuate (comparative more sinuate, superlative most sinuate)

entries.meaning: Having wavy indentation on its border or edge.
(mycology, of gills) Roughly the same height for most of its length, becoming much shallower and then curving back towards the stem before reaching the attachment point.
examples: In this group of mushrooms, the attachment of the gills to the stipe is sinuate.

verbs.description: sinuate (third-person singular simple present sinuates, present participle sinuating, simple past and past participle sinuated)

entries.meaning: To advance in wavy or curvy manner, to bend, to curve, to wind in and out
examples: A road that sinuates through the valley.
